name: GWI COVID-19
description: GWI data measuring how consumers are coping with COVID-19.
summary: --- {"editor":"simple"} --- **Data Origin:** GWI **Source Description:** Provided in this Dataset: - Pollpass study on the US/UK around Covid and consumer perceptions, behaviors, etc. Results attached. A summary Blog is [Here](https://protect-us.mimecast.com/s/5sV_CNkER4UVJLkOSmZ8gZ?domain=urldefense.proofpoint.com) - Pollpass study on the US/UK around Travel and commuting during Covid19 (attached). [Here](https://protect-us.mimecast.com/s/JY8dCOYER4i5lY17Ivpobw?domain=urldefense.proofpoint.com) is a blog that summarizes the results * 13 Market re-contact survey - Below is a description and summary of results. Study conducted in 13 markets - Australia, Brazil, China, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, Philippines, Singapore, South Africa, Spain, UK and the U.S. Anyone with a GWI user ID will be able to access this data and create audiences to profile against. Summary as follows: * **95% of consumers say they’re** **spending more time on in-home media consumption / activities** * Unsurprisingly, the biggest spike is for watching more news coverage; 2 in 3 are spending more time doing this (half of whom are spending _significantly _more time on it) * Over 50% are watching more streaming services, 45% are spending more time on messaging services, almost 45% are devoting more time to social media, and over 10% say they are creating / uploading videos * China, the Philippines, Spain and Italy lead for increased usage of streaming services (over 50% in each country) * Over 70% in the Philippines say they are spending longer on messaging services * Spain, Brazil and Italy are ahead for increased gaming (40%+) * Age can be a huge influencer over behaviors here; 16-24s are five times as likely as 55-64s to report increased usage of music streaming services, and almost six times as likely to be creating / uploading videos * **Smartphone usage is up significantly** * 70% globally say they are spending more time on their smartphone, rising to 80% among 16-24s * It’s a trend that remains consistent across income groups and by gender * Location makes a big difference: 77% of urban respondents are spending more time on their smartphones, compared to 47% of rural consumers * **There’s widespread belief that the 2020 Olympics should not go ahead** * Only 5% now think they should go ahead regardless, peaking at 7% in Japan and the U.S. * Some 46% think they should go ahead only if the outbreak is completely or mostly over, 36% think they should be postponed, and 12% think they should be cancelled * Even in host country Japan, just over 50% believe they should be postponed or cancelled * **Large purchases could be delayed for a long time** * Almost 40% say they will buy major purchases they have delayed only when the outbreak begins to decrease or is over in their country * But close to 20% say they will wait until the outbreak decreases or is over globally * The top income group have a notable lead for being open to making their purchases once the national situation begins to improve * **Concern about the local vs global situation varies – in part based on where a country is in its journey** * In China, around 25% are very / extremely concerned about the situation in their country, whereas over 50% say the same about the global situation * In countries like France, Spain, UK, and the U.S., the figures are much more equal – in each case, between 50-60% are very / extremely concerned about the situations globally and in their own market * **Almost three quarters of consumers are interested in live streams of postponed events** * Live streamed sports events and music concerts are equally popular – over 4 in 10 are interested in watching them * A further 20% are interested in live-streamed theater shows * Age is a strong influencer here; almost 50% of 55-64s aren’t interested in any live streaming, compared to around 20% of 16-24s and 25-34s * Interest in live music concert streams drops in line with age, whereas interest in theater holds relatively steady * 25-34s and 35-44s are the most interested in live sports streams * **There’s a disconnect between how people think this will impact their personal finances, vs what will happen to the national or global economy** * Across the 13 markets, 30% think it will have a big or dramatic impact on their personal finances. But over 75% think the same about their country’s economy, and over 85% think it will have a big or dramatic impact on the global economy * The biggest gaps are found in France, Germany, Italy, Japan and the UK, where there’s at least a 50-point difference between the smaller numbers expecting it to have a big or dramatic impact on their personal finances vs the higher numbers expecting it to hit their country’s economy **SAMPLE SIZES and WEIGHTING** All stats are from a GlobalWebIndex custom recontact survey fielded March 16-20 among 1,004 (Australia), 1,001 (Brazil), 1,003 (China), 1,016 (France), 1,010 (Germany), 1,010 (Italy), 1,079 (Japan), 1,008 (Philippines), 1,008 (Singapore), 573 (South Africa), 1,005 (Spain), 1,040 (UK) and 1,088 (U.S.) internet users aged 16-64. In the interests of speed, 1,000 responses per country (500 in South Africa) were collected. The responses in each country have been weighted according to GWI's usual age, gender and education framework. In some countries, GWI collected relatively few responses in the 16-24 or 55-64 groups; where necessary, they have therefore combined weightings with adjacent age groups. **When:** March 2020 ​

name: Handwriting Recognition
description: Transcriptions of 400,000 handwritten names for Optical Character Recognition (OCR).
summary: --- {"editor":"simple"} --- **Data Origin:** Figure Eight **Who:** Dataset owned and managed by WPP Data Catalogue **Source Description:** This dataset consists of more than four hundred thousand handwritten names collected through charity projects to support disadvantaged children around the world. Optical Character Recognition (OCR) utilizes image processing technologies to convert characters on scanned documents into digital forms. It typically performs well in machine printed fonts. However, it still poses a difficult challenges for machines to recognize handwritten characters, because of the huge variation in individual writing styles. There are 206,799 first names and 207,024 surnames in total. The data was divided into a training set (331,059), testing set (41,382), and validation set (41,382) respectively. Labels of all images created via human-in-the-loop anotation on the Figure-Eight platform are also provided, enabling you to extend the data set with your own data. **When:** 2020 **Auto-Sync:** Daily **Cite:** Handwriting Recognition, Figure Eight **Licensing:** Licensed under a [Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License](http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/). By taking the action of downloading any data set(s), you hereby agree to the associated license terms. Each data set is provided “as is” and any expressed or implied warranties, including, but not limited to, the implied warranties of merchantability and fitness for a particular purpose are disclaimed.

name: Health Insurance Marketplace
description: Summary Enrollment Data for the Initial Annual Open Enrollment Period
summary: --- {"editor":"simple"} --- **Data Origin:** US Department of Health and Human Services via data.world **Source Description:** This document contains state-level profiles that summarize key data relating to Affordable Care Act coverage expansion enrollment from the ASPE Health Insurance Marketplace Summary Enrollment Report For The Initial Annual Open Enrollment Period; For the period: October 1, 2013 - March 31, 2014 (Including Additional Special Enrollment Period Activity through 4-19-14), and the CMS Medicaid & CHIP: March 2014 Monthly Applications, Eligibility Determinations, and Enrollment Report. These profiles include data for states that are implementing their own Marketplaces (also known as State-Based Marketplaces or SBMs), and states with Marketplaces that are supported by or fully run by the Department of Health and Human Services (including those run in partnership with states, also known as the Federally-facilitated Marketplace or FFM). Data are provided on the number and characteristics of individuals who have selected a Marketplace plan (including those who have paid a premium and those who have not yet paid a premium, regardless of when their coverage began); and the change in Medicaid / CHIP enrollment, representing the difference between March 2014 enrollment and Pre-ACA Monthly Average Medicaid and CHIP Enrollment (July-Sept 2013). For more information, please see the Marketplace Summary Enrollment Report, which can be accessed [here](http://aspe.hhs.gov/health/reports/2014/MarketPlaceEnrollment/Apr2014/ib_2014Apr_enrollment.pdf), and the March Medicaid/CHIP Enrollment Report, which can be accessed [here](http://www.medicaid.gov/AffordableCareAct/Medicaid-Moving-Forward-2014/Downloads/March-2014-Enrollment-Report.pdf). _Source:_ [Department of Health and Human Services](https://catalog.data.gov/dataset/health-insurance-marketplace-summary-enrollment-data-for-the-initial-annual-open-enrollmen) **When:** 2020 **Auto-Sync:** Weekly **Cite:** Health Insurance Marketplace, US Department of Health and Human Services

name: Honeybee Population
description: Honey bee population data from 2012 to 2017 from the US Department of Agriculture.
summary: --- {"editor":"simple"} --- Data Origin: USDA **About the Data:** **Bee Colony Survey Data by State** data was retrieved from the [United States Department of Agriculture National Agricultural Statistics Service Quick Stats Dataset](https://quickstats.nass.usda.gov/) with the selection criteria shown in the file **Search criteria for bee colony survey** attached to this dataset. **Bee Colony Census Data by County** data was retrieved from the [United States Department of Agriculture National Agricultural Statistics Service Quick Stats Dataset](https://quickstats.nass.usda.gov/) with the selection criteria shown in the file **Search criteria for bee colony census by county** attached to this dataset. **Bee Colony Census Data by State** data was retrieved from the [United States Department of Agriculture National Agricultural Statistics Service Quick Stats Dataset](https://quickstats.nass.usda.gov/) with the selection criteria shown in the file **Search criteria for bee colony census by state** attached to this dataset. **Bee Informed data** The original **Bee Colony Loss** data is copyrighted and owned by the Bee Informed Partnership and is being used solely for educational purposes as permitted by the Bee Informed Partnership. The Bee Informed Partnership does not endorse this dataset and analysis. The original data can be found [here](https://bip2.beeinformed.org/loss-map/). Notes: * Slight variations, resulting from additional analyses, may occur between reported losses in publications and those shown on this map. * Responses for beekeepers that manage colonies in more than one state are included in the loss calculation for each state they keep bees in. * Percent of beekeepers exclusive to the state indicates the percent of responding beekeepers who do NOT keep bees in other states in addition to the state indicated here. * "Average loss" represents the average level of loss experienced by a beekeeper in its operation in the selected state. "Total loss" is the estimate of the number of colonies lost by the whole beekeeping population in that state. * For the protection of privacy, losses are reported as N/A if 5 or fewer beekeepers responded in that state. These beekeepers losses are included in the national statistics.

name: How beautiful is this image? (Buildings and Architecture)
description: Data set includes a URL for each image, an averaged score (of 1-5) for image quality, and a variance rating.
summary: --- {"editor":"simple"} --- **Data Origin:** Figure Eight **Who:** Dataset owned and managed by WPP Data Catalogue **What:** Here, contributors were asked to rate image _quality_ (as opposed to how gorgeous the buildings in the images actually are). They were given a five-point scale, from “unacceptable” (out-of-focus cityscapes) to “exceptional” (hi-res photos that might appear in a city guide book) and ranked a series of images based on that criteria. Data set includes a URL for each image, an averaged score (of 1-5) for image quality, and a variance rating accounting for subjective, contributor disagreements. **When:** 2014 **Auto-Sync:** Weekly **Cite:** How beautiful is this image? (Part 2: Buildings and Architecture), Figure Eight

name: IFC Advisory Services Projects

summary: --- {"editor":"markdown"} --- **Data Origin:** Open data linked via @worldbank **Who:** Dataset owned and managed by World Bank Group Finances **What:** Project data; Global Economy Coverage **When:** Data records exist from October 2012 until the Present **Type:** Cross Sectional **Updated:** Daily **Source Description:** "Private sector development requires more than just finance. Experience shows the powerful role advisory services can play in unlocking investment and helping businesses expand and create jobs. To help the private sector in emerging markets, IFC provides advice, problem solving, and training to companies, industries, and governments. Our experience shows that companies need more than financial investment to thrive. They need a regulatory environment that enables entrepreneurship, and advice on business best practices. Our work includes advising national and local governments on how to improve their investment climate and strengthen basic infrastructure. Governments account for around half of our advisory projects. We also help investment clients improve corporate governance and become more sustainable." For project information IFC discloses on a daily basis, please refer to the IFC Disclosure Portal: [http://www.ifc.org/disclosure](http://www.ifc.org/disclosure) **Cite:** World Bank Finances, World Bank This dataset is subject to these license terms, including attribution requirements and linking the license terms to: [Terms of Use for Datasets Listed in The World Bank Data Catalog](https://www.worldbank.org/en/about/legal/terms-of-use-for-datasets) **_Source:_** [http://finances.worldbank.org/d/b74b-t2z3](http://finances.worldbank.org/d/b74b-t2z3) ​ ​

name: Inclusive Internet Index 2020
description: The overall Index score based on the scores of the Availability, Affordability, Relevance and Readiness categories.
summary: --- {"editor":"simple"} --- **Data Origin:** [E](https://theinclusiveinternet.eiu.com/)conomist Intelligence Unit - Commissioned by Facebook **What: Description sourced directly from Executive Summary** The Inclusive Internet Index, commissioned by Facebook and conducted by The Economist Intelligence Unit, returns for its fourth year. The index provides a rigorous benchmark of national-level Internet inclusion in 100 countries across four categories: Availability, Affordability, Relevance and Readiness. This year’s index, which covers 91% of the world’s population, is published for a third year alongside the Value of the Internet Survey, which polled 4,953 respondents from 99 countries, to gauge perceptions on how Internet use affects people’s lives and livelihoods. This executive summary presents the index and survey highlights. Key findings: Internet access is increasing globally, but vast disparities remain and the rate of uptake is slowing in the hardest-to-reach areas. Mobile data has been a game-changer for lower-income groups, but access is still too expensive. Although narrowing, the gender gap in access remains stubbornly wide, particularly in low- and lower-middle-income countries. The Internet is facilitating people’s management of their money and finances and their inclusion in the broader economy. People are going online to prepare for the technology-intensive jobs of tomorrow. **When:** 2020 ​

name: International Financial Statistics (IFS)
description: International Financial Statistics database covers 200 countries and areas and various financial topics.
summary: --- {"editor":"markdown"} --- **Data Origin:** Open data linked via [@imf](https://data.world/imf) **Who:** Dataset owned and managed by International Monetary Fund **What:** * **Geographic Coverage:** IFS covers 194 countries and areas. Under the Fund’s legal framework, the member in effective control of a territory must report data respecting that territory. With respect to data on any territory whose status is the subject of a dispute between members, the IMF’s use of data on that territory provided by a member, either for surveillance or any other Fund activities, does not constitute a judgment by the IMF on the status of that territory. * **Methodology:** The International Financial Statistics is based on various IMF data collections. It includes exchange rates series for all Fund member countries plus Anguilla, Aruba, China, P.R.: Hong Kong, China, P.R.: Macao, Montserrat, and the Netherlands Antilles. It also includes major Fund accounts series, real effective exchange rates, and other world, area, and country series. Data are available for most IMF member countries with some aggregates calculated for select regions, plus some world totals. * **Sectoral Coverage:** Sectoral Coverage: National Accounts, Indicators of Economic Activity, Labor Markets, Prices, Government and Public Sector Finance, Financial Indicators, Balance of Payments, International Investment Position, International Reserves, Fund Accounts, External Trade, Exchange Rates, and Population. **When:** Data records exist from 1948 - current; Varies by country **Type:** Time Series **Updated:** Annually; Latest Update Data as of download - 02/24/2017 **Auto-Sync:** Weekly **Source Description:** "The International Financial Statistics database covers about 200 countries and areas, with some aggregates calculated for selected regions, plus some world totals. Topics covered include balance of payments, commodity prices, exchange rates, fund position, government finance, industrial production, interest rates, international investment position, international liquidity, international transactions, labor statistics, money and banking, national accounts, population, prices, and real effective exchange rates." **Cite:** International Financial Statistics, International Monetary Fund The Data is provided to Users “as is” and without warranty of any kind, either express or implied, including, without limitation, warranties of merchantability, fitness for a particular purpose and noninfringement. The IMF Data is available free of charge from the IMF. Users are prohibited from infringing upon the integrity of the IMF data and in particular shall refrain from any act of alteration of the IMF data that intentionally affects its nature or accuracy. If the IMF data is materially transformed by the user, this must be stated explicitly along with the required source citation. All other terms set forth in the IMF's general terms and conditions ([http://www.imf.org/external/terms.htm](http://www.imf.org/external/terms.htm)) shall continue to apply to use of IMF Data. **_Source:_** [http://data.imf.org/?sk=388DFA60-1D26-4ADE-B505-A05A558D9A42&sId=1479329132340](http://data.imf.org/?sk=388DFA60-1D26-4ADE-B505-A05A558D9A42&sId=1479329132340)

Data set contains all nouns and aggregated T/F judgments. **When:** 2015 **Auto-Sync:** Weekly **Cite:** Free Text Object Descriptions, Figure Eight

name: Italian COVID-19 Quarantine Report
description: Used public data and visual AI to identify violations.
summary: --- {"editor":"simple"} --- **Data Origin:** Logograb **Source Description:** This description was sourced directly from [Logograb.](https://blog.logograb.com/covid19-visual-ai-analysis-lockdown-violation-italy/) _"More and more countries are tightening their rules around movement and physical distance to help mitigate the spread of COVID-19. While most of us are doing all we can to support this effort, social media has been littered with posts of people ignoring their health ministries’ advice and regulations, causing distress to citizens, health workers and government officials all the world over._ _Italy is one of the worst affected areas in the world and, despite this, many of the country’s citizens did not initially follow the [government’s decree](http://http//www.governo.it/it/faq-iorestoacasa), putting more lives at risk._ _LogoGrab’s co-founders, Luca Boschin and Alessandro Prest are Italian citizens, as are many of the company’s employees, seeing news reports of Italians posting photos on social media showing them ignoring the lockdown rules was a source of great worry and distress. They decided to do something about it._ _They spent some time looking at how LogoGrabs Visual-AI technology could be put to practical use to help reduce the spread of COVID-19. They ultimately merged a number of AI modules typically used for brand monitoring, and applied it in collaboration with Ghost Data, to a set of anonymised data to identify the level and types of violations during the initial period of the lockdown."_ **_What The Report Revealed_** 1. _50% of people not conforming to quarantine were taking part in group activities_ 2. _40% of Italians not confirming were in the city, while 26% were spending time at the beach and 17% were out in parks and parkland_ 3. _The highest levels of quarantine violations were in the regions of Lombardy, Campania, Sicily and Lazio_ _[Logograb Blog -- How (and Why) We Used Visual-AI to Highlight COVID-19 Lcokdown Violation in Italy](https://blog.logograb.com/covid19-visual-ai-analysis-lockdown-violation-italy/)_ For additional information on the report, data, and licensing, please visit [Logograb's website](https://blog.logograb.com/covid19-visual-ai-analysis-lockdown-violation-italy/). **When:** March 2020

name: Judge Emotion About Brands & Products
description: Contributors evaluated tweets about multiple brands and products.
summary: --- {"editor":"simple"} --- **Data Origin:** Figure Eight **Who:** Dataset owned and managed by WPP Data Catalogue **What:** Contributors evaluated tweets about multiple brands and products. The crowd was asked if the tweet expressed positive, negative, or no emotion towards a brand and/or product. If some emotion was expressed they were also asked to say which brand or product was the target of that emotion. **When:** 2020 **Auto-Sync:** NA **Cite:** Judge Emotion About Brands & Products, Figure Eight

name: Judge emotions about nuclear energy from Twitter
description: Collection of tweets related to nuclear energy along with the crowd’s evaluation of the tweet’s sentiment.
summary: --- {"editor":"simple"} --- **Data Origin:** Figure Eight **Who:** Dataset owned and managed by WPP Data Catalogue **What:** This dataset is a collection of tweets related to nuclear energy along with the crowd’s evaluation of the tweet’s sentiment. The possible sentiment categories are: “Positive,” “Negative,” “Neutral/author is just sharing information,” “Tweet NOT related to nuclear energy,” and “I can’t tell.” We also provide an estimation of the crowds’ confidence that each category is correct which can be used to identify tweets whose sentiment may be unclear. **When:** 2013 **Auto-Sync:** Weekly **Cite:** Judge Emotion About Nuclear Energy from Twitter, Figure Eight

name: Judge the relatedness of familiar words and made-up words
description: Contributors were given a sentence with the nonce word in it and asked to note relation between the two.
summary: --- {"editor":"simple"} --- **Data Origin:** Figure Eight **Who:** Dataset owned and managed by WPP Data Catalogue **What:** Contributors were given a nonce word and a real word, for example, “leebaf” and “iguana.” They were given a sentence with the nonce word in it and asked to note how related the nonce word and real word were. Here’s a sample question: “Large numbers of leebaf skins are exported to Latin America to be made into handbags, shoes and watch straps.” Contributors then ranked the relation of “leebaf” to “iguana” on a scale of 1-5, from completely unrelated to very strongly related, respectively. **When:** 2014 **Auto-Sync:** Weekly **Cite:** Judge the relatedness of familiar words and made-up ones, Figure Eight

name: BrandZ Data - GSS & GCS
description: Contains the MDF Global Summary Spreadsheet and Global Category Spreadsheet
summary: --- {"editor":"simple"} --- **Data Origin:** BrandZ **What:** **All the key BrandZ metrics\* available to you in Excel\*\*** Choose the Excel spreadsheet that meets your data requirements: 1. The **[MDF ](https://mb.brandz.com/media/226619/MDF_GSS_WITHOUT_CITIES_25_Jan_2020.xlsx)[Global Summary Spreadsheet](https://mb.brandz.com/media/226619/MDF_GSS_WITHOUT_CITIES_25_Jan_2020.xlsx)** (MDF GSS) contains brand-level data. Explanations of the measures are included on a separate tab. Among the measures included: * Power, Premium and Potential * Meaningful, Different, Salient * Brand typology * Brand awareness and usage * Attributes/images (drivers of M, D, S) * TrustR and ReputationZ * CharacterZ typology and indices * Vitality Quotient and component indices 1. The **[Global Category Spreadsheet](https://mb.brandz.com/media/226607/MDF_Category_WITHOUT_CITIES_25_01_2020.xlsx)** contains category-level data. Among the measures included: * Consumer typology (Brand Loyal, Repertoire, Price-driven) * Brand and category importance * Category averages * Sample demographics * Online habits \*Data is updated regularly—approximately every two weeks while studies are being conducted. \*\*Please **DO NOT share** these files with clients. (You may share certain data, e.g. Power and MDS scores **for their category**, but the files themselves should not be shared.) [Click here](https://mb.brandz.com/media/217164/GSS-intro.mp4) to watch a video guide to the GSS. **When:** Updates every 2 weeks **Auto-Sync:** Weekly **Cite:** Browse the Data, BrandZ ​ ​

name: Medicaid Enrolled Provider Listing
description: This dataset is a list of active Medicaid Providers.
summary: --- {"editor":"simple"} --- **Data Origin:** Health Data New York via data.world **Source Description:** This dataset is a list of active Medicaid Fee-for-Service (FFS); Managed Care Only; and Ordering, Prescribing, Referring, Attending (OPRA) providers. Data elements include the provider’s Medicaid Provider ID, NPI, provider or facility name, Medicaid type, profession or service, provider specialty, service address, city, state, zip code, county, telephone number, latitude, longitude, enrollment begin date, next anticipated revalidation date and date the file was extracted from the data warehouse. For additional information, visit [https://www.health.ny.gov/health\_care/managed\_care/](https://www.health.ny.gov/health_care/managed_care/). Source: [https://health.data.ny.gov/d/keti-qx5t](https://health.data.ny.gov/d/keti-qx5t) Before using the data, download the Terms of Service [here](https://data.ny.gov/download/77gx-ii52/application/pdf) to read the data license requirements. **When:** 2020 **Auto-Sync:** Weekly **Cite:** Medicaid Enrolled Provider Listing, Health Data New York ​

name: Medical Information Extraction
description: Relationships between medical terms in PubMed articles, for relation extraction and related NLP tasks.
summary: --- {"editor":"simple"} --- **Data Origin:** Figure Eight **Who:** Dataset owned and managed by WPP Data Catalogue **Source Description:** This dataset contains 3,984 medical sentences extracted from PubMed abstracts and relationships between discrete medical terms were annotated. This dataset focuses primarily on “treat” and “cause” relationships, with 1,043 sentences containing treatment relations and 1,787 containing causal ones. Human-in-the-loop annotators were given two different terms (such as “Lewy Body Dementia” and “Well-formed Visual Hallucinations”) and were asked to mark the relationship between those terms (in this case “Lewy Body Dementia **causes** Well-Formed Visual Hallucinations). This corpus has been referenced in the following papers: * Anca Dumitrache, Lora Aroyo, Chris Welty: _CrowdTruth Measures for Language Ambiguity: The Case of Medical Relation Extraction_. LD4IE at ISWC 2015. * Anca Dumitrache, Lora Aroyo, Chris Welty: _Achieving Expert-Level Annotation Quality with CrowdTruth: The Case of Medical Relation Extraction_. BDM2I at ISWC 2015.**When:** 2020 **Auto-Sync:** Daily **Cite:** Medical Information Extraction, Figure Eight **Licensing:** Licensed under a [Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License](http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/). By taking the action of downloading any data set(s), you hereby agree to the associated license terms. Each data set is provided “as is” and any expressed or implied warranties, including, but not limited to, the implied warranties of merchantability and fitness for a particular purpose are disclaimed.

name: Medical Speech, Transcription, and Intent (English)
description: 8.5 hours of audio utterances paired with text for common medical symptoms.
summary: --- {"editor":"simple"} --- **Data Origin:** Figure Eight **Source Description:** This data contains thousands of audio utterances for common medical symptoms like “knee pain” or “headache,” totaling more than 8 hours in aggregate. Each utterance was created by individual human contributors based on a given symptom. These audio snippets can be used to train conversational agents in the medical field. This Figure Eight dataset was created via a multi-job workflow. The first involved contributors writing text phrases to describe symptoms given. For example, for “headache,” a contributor might write “I need help with my migraines.” Subsequent jobs captured audio utterances for accepted text strings. This dataset contains both the audio utterances and corresponding transcriptions. **When:** 2020 **Auto-Sync:** Daily **Cite:** Medical Speech, Transcription, and Intent (English), Figure Eight **Licensing:** Licensed under a [Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License](http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/). By taking the action of downloading any data set(s), you hereby agree to the associated license terms. Each data set is provided “as is” and any expressed or implied warranties, including, but not limited to, the implied warranties of merchantability and fitness for a particular purpose are disclaimed.

The National Coverage Documents include: National Coverage Determinations (NCDs), National Coverage Analyses (NCAs), Coding Analyses for Labs (CALs), Medicare Evidence Development & Coverage Advisory Committee (MEDCAC) meetings, and Medicare coverage guidance documents. Please review the license agreement [here](https://www.cms.gov/medicare-coverage-database/license/cpt-license.aspx?from=~/overview-and-quick-search.aspx&npage=/medicare-coverage-database/downloads/downloadable-databases.aspx). **When:** 2020 **Auto-Sync:** Weekly **Cite:** Medicare Coverage Database, CMS

name: Medicare Geographic Variation
description: Geographic variation in the utilization and quality of health care services for the Medicare fee-for-service population.
summary: --- {"editor":"simple"} --- **Data Origin:** CMS **Source Description:** The Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) has developed a public use file that enables researchers and policymakers to evaluate geographic variation in the utilization and quality of health care services for the Medicare fee-for-service population. The Geographic Variation Public Use File includes demographic, spending, utilization, and quality indicators at the state level (including the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, and the Virgin Islands), hospital referral region (HRR) level, and county level. The Geographic Variation Public Use File has twelve separate files – two files with state and county-level data, four files with only state-level data, and six files with HRR-level data. The files are presented in two different formats. The “Table” files present indicators for all states, counties, or HRRs, and can easily be exported from Excel to another data analysis program for additional analysis, while the corresponding “Report” files allow users to compare a specific state, county, or HRR to national Medicare benchmarks. The state- and HRR-level data include age breakouts (under 65, and 65 or older). Each file has a Documentation section which explains the individual indicators in more detail. Information on the sample population and the methodology used to calculate these indicators can be found in the Methodological Overview paper and the Technical Supplement on Standardization paper. **When:** 2020 **Auto-Sync:** Daily **Cite:** Medicare Geographic Variation, Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services

name: Metadata Descriptors
description: Maximum of 120 characters - brief description of the dataset.
summary: --- {"editor":"simple"} --- **Data Origin:** Where did the data originate? What sources were used? **Dataset Summary:** Longer explanation of the dataset. Include purpose, methodology, previous and potential uses of the dataset. **When:** When was the data last updated? When was it collected / generated / last accessed? **Citation:** Include for others to use if necessary. **Terms of Use / Licensing Agreement:** If licensed, select appropriate license type in sidebar. Include terms of use or agreement here when necessary. ​ **Guide to Dataset Statuses:** One of the 3 statuses should be assigned to each dataset. Other statuses existing in the dropdown are relevant to Business Glossary terms. * **Sample:** Assigned to training datasets and projects only - very few datasets and projects will have this label assigned * **Pending:** Status assigned to all newly created datasets until marked as Verified by Data Steward. * **Verified:** Data Steward has approved the dataset and has marked the dataset as Verified. Permissions to view can then extend beyond the Dataset Owner, Content Contributor, and Data Steward. ​ ​

name: Middle East and Central Asia Regional Economic Outlook
description: Middle East and Central Asia Regional Economic Outlook (MCDREO)
summary: --- {"editor":"simple"} --- **Data Origin:** Open data linked via [@imf](https://data.world/imf) **Who:** Dataset owned and managed by International Monetary Fund **What:** * **Geographic Coverage:** Middle East and Central Asia * **Methodology:** MCD REO follows WEO methodology * **Sectoral Coverage:** NA **When:** Annual Data **Type:** Time Series **Updated:** Latest Update Data as of download - 10/19/2016 **Auto-Sync:** Weekly **Source Description:** "Economic developments in the Middle East, North Africa, Afghanistan, and Pakistan (MENAP) continue to reflect the diversity of conditions prevailing across the region. Most high-income oil exporters, primarily in the GCC, continue to record steady growth and solid economic and financial fundamentals, albeit with medium-term challenges that need to be addressed. In contrast, other countries --Iraq, Libya, Syria -- mired in conflicts with not just humanitarian but also economic consequences. And yet other countries, mostly oil importers, are making continued but uneven progress in advancing their economic agenda, often in tandem with political transitions and amidst difficult social conditions. In most of these countries, without extensive economic and structural reforms, economic prospects for the medium term remain insufficient to reduce high unemployment and improve living standards. Economic activity in the Caucasus and Central Asia (CCA) region is weakening, mainly because of the near-term slowdown and rising regional tensions affecting Russia, a key trading partner and sources of remittance and investment inflows, as well as weaker domestic demand in a number of CCA countries. Near-term risks are to the downside and tied to the fortunes of large trading partners. Policies need to focus on bolstering economic stability and, where needed, short-term support to ailing economic growth. In addition, a new model for high, sustained, diversified, and inclusive growth is needed to set the direction for economic policies for the next decade." **Cite:** MCDREO, International Monetary Fund The Data is provided to Users “as is” and without warranty of any kind, either express or implied, including, without limitation, warranties of merchantability, fitness for a particular purpose and noninfringement. The IMF Data is available free of charge from the IMF. Users are prohibited from infringing upon the integrity of the IMF data and in particular shall refrain from any act of alteration of the IMF data that intentionally affects its nature or accuracy. If the IMF data is materially transformed by the user, this must be stated explicitly along with the required source citation. All other terms set forth in the IMF's general terms and conditions ([http://www.imf.org/external/terms.htm](http://www.imf.org/external/terms.htm)) shall continue to apply to use of IMF Data. **_Source:_** [http://data.imf.org/?sk=388DFA60-1D26-4ADE-B505-A05A558D9A42&sId=1479329132343](http://data.imf.org/?sk=388DFA60-1D26-4ADE-B505-A05A558D9A42&sId=1479329132343)

name: Millennium Development Goals
description: Indicators drawn from the World Development Indicators, reorganized according to the Millennium Development Goals (MDG)
summary: --- {"editor":"markdown"} --- **Data Origin:** Open data linked via @worldbank **Who:** Dataset owned and managed by World Bank Group **What:** National data; Global Geographic and Economic Coverage **When:** Data records exist from 1990 until 2015. **Type:** Time Series **Updated:** No further updates planned. **Source Description:** "Relevant indicators drawn from the World Development Indicators, reorganized according to the goals and targets of the [Millennium Development Goals (MDGs)](http://www5.worldbank.org/mdgs/), covering 1990 - 2014. The 8 MDGs are to: 1. To eradicate extreme poverty and hunger 2. To achieve universal primary education 3. To promote gender equality and empower women to reduce child mortality 4. To improve maternal health 5. To combat HIV/AIDS, malaria, and other diseases 6. To ensure environmental sustainability 7. To develop a global partnership for development The Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) are the world's time-bound and quantified targets for addressing extreme poverty in its many dimensions - income, poverty, hunger, disease, lack of adequate shelter, and exclusion - while promoting gender equality, education, and environmental sustainability." **Cite:** Attribution: [Millennium Development Goals, The World Bank](http://data.worldbank.org/data-catalog/millennium-development-indicators). [World Bank Data Catalog Terms of Use](https://www.worldbank.org/en/about/legal/terms-of-use-for-datasets) **_Source:_** [http://data.worldbank.org/data-catalog/millennium-development-indicators](http://data.worldbank.org/data-catalog/millennium-development-indicators)

name: Mindshare - Chart of the Week - Alcohol & Youth
description: Mindshare's Chart of the Week explores "Does today's youth drink more or less alcohol?"
summary: --- {"editor":"simple"} --- **Data Origin:** Mindshare **Who:** Dataset owned and managed by WPP Data Catalogue **What:** Mindshare's Chart of the Week - Data exploring whether today's youth consumer more or less alcohol. Everyone’s behaviour is affected by their culture, including their drinking habits. However, the pattern of alcohol consumption is changing among the youth. Some countries, mainly low-income ones with a fast-growing GDP per capita, have more young drinkers compared to previous years due to an increase in their disposable income. While in other countries, especially high-income ones, the number of young people choosing to be abstemious has increased. In these countries, the younger generations are more aware of the financial, social and health issues associated with drinking heavily. Check out our Chart of the Week to find out more information. **When:** 30 September 2019 **Auto-Sync:** NA **Cite:** Chart of the Week, Mindshare, WPP Data Catalogue

name: Mindshare - Chart of the Week - Baby Boomers
description: Mindshare's Chart of the Week explores "How polarised are Baby Boomers around the world?"
summary: --- {"editor":"simple"} --- **Data Origin:** Mindshare **Who:** Dataset owned and managed by WPP Data Catalogue **What:** Mindshare's Chart of the Week - Data exploring how polarised Baby Boomers are around the world (by country) With an ever increasing life expectancy, we should not write off individuals over 55’s as old. By 2020 this age group will have triple the spending power of Millennials, according to Euromonitor. To get to know them more, our Chart of the Week explores the polarising thoughts of Baby Boomers and how they vary around the world. One example, comparing APAC to the Nordics, who do you think is more likely to agree with the statement “The rules are made to be broken”? **When:** 11 November 2019 **Auto-Sync:** NA **Cite:** Chart of the Week, Mindshare, WPP Data Catalogue

name: Mindshare - Chart of the Week - Celebrity Fashion Influence
description: Mindshare's Chart of the Week explores the influence of celebrities in fashion across the globe.
summary: --- {"editor":"simple"} --- **Data Origin:** Mindshare **Who:** Dataset owned and managed by WPP Data Catalogue **What:** Mindshare's Chart of the Week - Data exploring the influence celebrities have on fashion and beauty purchases across the globe. Brands have been a part of media and celebrity culture for decades. Online shop Boohoo have collections based on the characters on the reality show Love Island UK and it has become the brand most associated with the TV program on Twitter, as contestants wear Booho brand clothes every night. Does interest in celebrities predict the likelihood that a consumer will purchase fashion? Mindreader shows that 36% of global respondents are interested in showbiz/celebrity gossip and this audience is more likely than the total population to purchase apparel online monthly (129ix.). **When:** 29 July 2019 **Auto-Sync:** NA **Cite:** Chart of the Week, Mindshare, WPP Data Catalogue

name: Mindshare - Chart of the Week - Content Consumption
description: Mindshare's Chart of the Week explores "Does content consumption change when people becomes parents?"
summary: --- {"editor":"simple"} --- **Data Origin:** Mindshare **Who:** Dataset owned and managed by WPP Data Catalogue **What:** Mindshare's Chart of the Week - Data exploring whether content consumption changes when people become parents. Having children is universally recognised as one of the milestones that prompts the most changes in our behaviour, habits and lifestyle. The question is – does it also modify our interest in different types of video content? Globally, parents that live with their kids increase their interest in any type of Film or TV content regardless of the genre. Unsurprisingly, it also causes a substantial interest on family and children content (29% more compared to the those living on their own, with friends or with their partner). Despite that, comedy and action/adventure remain the top two favourite genres while documentaries and drama appear unaffected by parenthood. **When:** 14 October 2019 **Auto-Sync:** NA **Cite:** Chart of the Week, Mindshare, WPP Data Catalogue

name: Mindshare - Chart of the Week - Cooking Gender Roles
description: Mindshare's Chart of the Week explores whether men cook at home.
summary: --- {"editor":"simple"} --- **Data Origin:** Mindshare **Who:** Dataset owned and managed by WPP Data Catalogue **What:** Mindshare's Chart of the Week - Data exploring gender roles in cooking across the globe, specifically: Do men cook at home? Globally, 53% of men say they do often cook at home vs. 47% who say they don’t. Younger generations seem to be more open to cooking than the older ones (except for the 18-24 y.o. who still live with their parents). The internet has made it easier to access recipes, however, males’ aversion to spending time in the kitchen could be due to different factors: older men still expect women to cook, whereas younger men are overwhelmed with their hectic lives. Culture also has also a profound effect on males’ propensity to prepare food: in some countries, men are not expected to cook or eating out is very common; in others, males help more at home (especially if they are fathers) or eat healthier. Brands and media must consider the peculiarities by country and age before capitalising on this global trend. **When:** 23 September 2019 **Auto-Sync:** NA **Cite:** Chart of the Week, Mindshare, WPP Data Catalogue ​

name: Mindshare - Chart of the Week - Debt
description: Mindshare's Chart of the Week explores "Are people are worried about the amount of money they owe?"
summary: --- {"editor":"simple"} --- **Data Origin:** Mindshare **Who:** Dataset owned and managed by WPP Data Catalogue **What:** Mindshare's Chart of the Week - Data exploring whether people are worried about the amount of money they owe. Worrying about money is so ingrained in our culture that it has become an epidemic. Not making enough money, spending too much, or stressing about an uncertain future can cause worry. Globally, 34% of the online adults are anxious about owing cash. According to Mindreader, Portugal is the country where more people express worry about the amount of money they owe (71%). In contrast, in the Netherlands, less than 2 in 10 agree with the same statement. Mindreader reveals this information in our weekly chart. **When:** 2 December 2019 **Auto-Sync:** NA **Cite:** Chart of the Week, Mindshare, WPP Data Catalogue

name: Mindshare - Chart of the Week - Digital Divide
description: Mindshare's Chart of the Week explores "Does the digital divide between generations still exist?"
summary: --- {"editor":"simple"} --- **Data Origin:** Mindshare **Who:** Dataset owned and managed by WPP Data Catalogue **What:** Mindshare's Chart of the Week - Data exploring whether the digital divide between generations still exists. Simple answer, yes! As technology continues to evolve, Baby Boomers (55+) are not as interested in the latest technology as the younger generations and stick to more traditional media forms. Globally, they favour owning a standard desktop computer (68%, 94ix) over a tablet (43%, 89ix). Alternatively, Gen Z and Millennials live their lives through technology, queuing outside the likes of Apple and Samsung in the early hours, just to keep up with the latest gadgets. Mindreader shows that 18-34 are more likely than the total population to own the latest technology (VR headsets, wearable cameras, drones, smartwatches and music streaming services) globally. Check out the chart of the week to see how this differs between country to country. **When:** 4 November 2019 **Auto-Sync:** NA **Cite:** Chart of the Week, Mindshare, WPP Data Catalogue

name: Mindshare - Chart of the Week - Environmentalist Behaviors
description: Mindshare's Chart of the Week explores whether or not environmentalists behave in accordance with their principles.
summary: --- {"editor":"markdown"} --- **Data Origin:** Mindshare **Who:** Dataset owned and managed by WPP Data Catalogue **What:** Mindshare's Chart of the Week - Data exploring the behaviors of environmentalists and whether they are in accordance with environmentalist principles. Globally, 35% of the online population (18+) supported environmental causes last year. This audience tends to buy products that are environmentally friendly (50%, 134 ix.), and to buy local products to support the communities that they live in (43%, 124 ix.). In both scenarios, environmentalists are more likely than average to showcase sustainable purchasing habits. Consumers’ desire to purchase sustainable products has encouraged brands to consider their carbon footprint; it’s better for the planet and it makes good business sense. **When:** Uploaded January 2020 **Auto-Sync:** NA **Cite:** Chart of the Week, Mindshare, WPP Data Catalogue Show less

name: Mindshare - Chart of the Week - Fashion & Gaming
description: Mindshare's Chart of the Week explores the question, "Do fashion brands have a place in the gaming world?
summary: --- {"editor":"simple"} --- **Data Origin:** Mindshare **Who:** Dataset owned and managed by WPP Data Catalogue **What:** Mindshare's Chart of the Week - Data exploring whether fashion brands have a space in the gaming world. Gaming has caught the attention of fashion in recent times. Nike is crossing over to games like Fortnite with their Air Jordans, eSports teams like Team Liquid are releasing jerseys in partnership with Marvel and now even luxury companies such as Louis Vuitton are getting involved with competitive gaming. But how easy will it be for these fashion brands to win over gamers? It’s clear that women who play games share a high passion for the category but most people interested in eSports are men (64%, 126ix. according to Mindreader). How interested would gamers be in seeing more beauty/fashion brands get involved with the industry? See the stats by market in our Chart of the Week. **When:** 30 September 2019 **Auto-Sync:** NA **Cite:** Chart of the Week, Mindshare, WPP Data Catalogue

name: Mindshare - Chart of the Week - Fighting Online Ads
description: Mindshare's Chart of the Week exploring the topic of "Fighting Online Ads"
summary: --- {"editor":"simple"} --- **Data Origin:** Mindshare **Who:** Dataset owned and managed by WPP Data Catalogue **What:** Mindshare's Chart of the Week - Data exploring: Fighting Online Ads; Explores ad blocking by country The use of ad blocking software became popular in 2015 and while people still use them, brands fight against it by asking you to remove your ad block to access their content. Mindreader tell us which countries people use the most or the least ad blocking. **When:** Uploaded January 2020 **Auto-Sync:** NA **Cite:** Chart of the Week, Mindshare, WPP Data Catalogue

name: Mindshare - Chart of the Week - Future Online Banking
description: Mindshare's Chart of the Week explores the future landscape of online banking and readiness levels.
summary: --- {"editor":"simple"} --- **Data Origin:** Mindshare **Who:** Dataset owned and managed by WPP Data Catalogue **What:** Mindshare's Chart of the Week - Data exploring the future of the online banking landscape and readiness levels. New technologies (i.e. voice and facial recognition), start-ups (i.e. Monzo and Starling) and new business models (i.e. Curve) are disrupting the online banking sector. Is everyone ready for these technological changes? Globally, 80% of the online adult population use online internet banking. Couples with no children (Established) and families with small or school children are the ones that use digital banking the most and are more likely to do it daily compared to other demographics. These groups are in their 30s and 40s, however, the consumption of internet banking decreases with the oldest audiences. **When:** 9 September 2019 **Auto-Sync:** NA **Cite:** Chart of the Week, Mindshare, WPP Data Catalogue

name: Mindshare - Chart of the Week - Gender & Identity
description: Mindshare's Chart of the Week explores "How important is gender to our self-identity?"
summary: --- {"editor":"simple"} --- **Data Origin:** Mindshare **Who:** Dataset owned and managed by WPP Data Catalogue **What:** Mindshare's Chart of the Week - Data exploring how important gender is to our self-identity. With the rise in discussion around toxic masculinity and the escalation of the ‘Me too’ movement in recent years, our perception of our own gender identity is more heightened than it has ever been before. According to Mindreader, globally 58% of men say their sex, being male or female, is important to them when considering their self-identity, compared to 54% of women. This trend remains the same across the Gen X, Gen Y and Baby Boomer generations, men globally appear to value their gender in higher esteem than women and not surprisingly Millennials in general, regard their sex as more significant to their identity than older ages groups. **When:** 6 January 2020 **Auto-Sync:** NA **Cite:** Chart of the Week, Mindshare, WPP Data Catalogue

name: Mindshare - Chart of the Week - Gender & Identity P2
description: Mindshare's Chart of the Week continues its exploration of "How important is gender to our self-identity?" in Part II
summary: --- {"editor":"simple"} --- **Data Origin:** Mindshare **Who:** Dataset owned and managed by WPP Data Catalogue **What:** Mindshare's Chart of the Week - Data continues its exploration of "How important is gender to our self-identity?" Last week we learned from our Chart of the Week that for men their gender is more important for their self-identity than for women. So, has the ‘Me too’ and the ‘Toxic Masculinity’ movement had any effect? According to Mindreader the answer is “yes”. Both males and females value their gender identity significantly more than they did three years ago, this has especially increased for young women (18-34). Meanwhile, the growth of men being proud of their gender was higher for the older generations (45+) than for the younger ones (18-34). Find these differences by country in our Chart of the Week. **When:** 13 January 2020 **Auto-Sync:** NA **Cite:** Chart of the Week, Mindshare, WPP Data Catalogue

name: Mindshare - Chart of the Week - Good Samaritans
description: Mindshare's Chart of the Week focused on "Samaritans for a better world"
summary: --- {"editor":"simple"} --- **Data Origin:** Mindshare **Who:** Dataset owned and managed by WPP Data Catalogue **What:** Mindshare's Chart of the Week - Data exploring "Samaritans for a better world." Global coverage includes the following topics: environmental, community development, health, education, arts and culture, international NGO's, human services, religion, politics, and equality. Female teenagers, Greta Thunberg, Masala Yousafzai, Emma Gonzalez and Jazz Jennings, are environmental, educational, political and equality activists who stand up for their beliefs. Fortunately, they don’t stand alone. With almost 40% of the global population volunteering or helpings others there is a large group of people also willing to stand together. Our Chart of the Week illustrates the main causes this group supports compared to the country population. **When:** 5 August 2019 **Auto-Sync:** NA **Cite:** Chart of the Week, Mindshare, WPP Data Catalogue

name: Mindshare - Chart of the Week - Grocery Shopping & Gender
description: Mindshare's chart of the week explores "Are women still the main grocery shoppers?"
summary: --- {"editor":"simple"} --- **Data Origin:** Mindshare **Who:** Dataset owned and managed by WPP Data Catalogue **What:** Mindshare's Chart of the Week - Data exploring gender roles in grocery shopping, specifically - are women still the primary grocery shoppers? When it comes to household grocery shopping, brands tend to focus in one gender only. In this fast-paced environment consumers can find quickly find information, trusteed reviews and discounts anywhere anytime, and even get products delivered home. Hence, companies can’t miss the opportunity of targeting both genders. As Mindreader reveals men grocery shop just as much as women globally. Male make up 43.6% of main grocery buyers vs. 45.7% of female. When it comes to non-main grocery shoppers this proportion becomes more unequal (7.0% vs. 3.4%). **When:** 16 September 2019 **Auto-Sync:** NA **Cite:** Chart of the Week, Mindshare, WPP Data Catalogue

name: Mindshare - Chart of the Week - Laws vs. Technology
description: Mindshare's Chart of the Week containing data around laws vs. technology
summary: --- {"editor":"simple"} --- **Data Origin:** Mindshare **Who:** Dataset owned and managed by WPP Data Catalogue **What:** Mindshare's Chart of the Week - Data supporting: Laws vs. Technology; Containts measurement of the degree to which technology is progressing faster than society; Global coverage According to Mindreader, only 11% of global early adopters (people who agree to be the first one in their group of friends that have the latest technology) own a drone – almost double than the global population. In the EU, legislations distinguish between recreational and professional use of drones, with the latter one able to profit from taking images or videos. Even though 74% of global people agree that technology is progressing faster than society, regulations are not stopping the technology revolution. **When:** Uploaded January 2020 **Auto-Sync:** NA **Cite:** Chart of the Week, Mindshare, WPP Data Catalogue

name: Mindshare - Chart of the Week - Media for Discovery
description: Mindshare's Chart of the Week: Media for Discovery
summary: --- {"editor":"simple"} --- **Data Origin:** Mindshare **Who:** Dataset owned and managed by WPP Data Catalogue **What:** Mindshare's Chart of the Week - Data exploring the media forms used by adults for discovery of information. Using Mindreader data we can delve deeper into how adults use media for discovery. Not really a surprise that TV is no longer the mythical creature that opened doors to a new world for children, but what we can see is that printed newspapers and magazines as well as their digital versions play an important role as discovery media sources for adults globally. What is also not surprising is that all discovery is being accessed through portable devices. **When:** Uploaded January 2020 **Auto-Sync:** NA **Cite:** Chart of the Week, Mindshare, WPP Data Catalogue

name: Mindshare - Chart of the Week - Online Shopping
description: Mindshare's Chart of the Week explores "Are people addicted to online shopping?"
summary: --- {"editor":"simple"} --- **Data Origin:** Mindshare **Who:** Dataset owned and managed by WPP Data Catalogue **What:** Mindshare's Chart of the Week - Data exploring whether people are addicted to online shopping. As Black Friday and Cyber Monday deals appear everywhere, retailers hope to outperform their record-breaking figures from 2018. Amazon was one of the retailers that benefitted the most in 2018, they sold 18m toys and 13m fashion items on both days combined. According to Mindreader, 8% of the global online population use the Amazon website several times a day, and a third of these individuals are making an online purchase every day. The latter figure rises to 2 in 5 when looking at young adults (18-34). Are we becoming addicted to online shopping? **When:** 25 November 2019 **Auto-Sync:** NA **Cite:** Chart of the Week, Mindshare, WPP Data Catalogue

name: Mindshare - Chart of the Week - Public Transport or Taxi
description: Mindshare's chart of the week exploring: public transport or taxi commuters, who enjoys more the internet?
summary: --- {"editor":"simple"} --- **Data Origin:** Mindshare **Who:** Dataset owned and managed by WPP Data Catalogue **What:** Mindshare's Chart of the Week - Data exploring: Public transport or taxi commuters - who enjoys more the internet? Commuting time has increased in recent years driven by changes in working patterns, transport infrastructure and a growing population. 65% of the global population uses public transport and 44% uses taxis weekly. When using public transport or taxis, people can focus more on themselves as they are not doing any other activity. Taxi users are more likely to daily consume instant messaging, sports news, online banking and entertainment content than those commuting by public transport. You can find more insights and explore differences across countries in our Chart of the Week. **When:** 12 August 2019 **Auto-Sync:** NA **Cite:** Chart of the Week, Mindshare, WPP Data Catalogue

name: Mindshare - Chart of the Week - Relationships
description: Mindshare's Chart of the Week explores "Are the boundaries of relationships becoming more open?"
summary: --- {"editor":"simple"} --- **Data Origin:** Mindshare **Who:** Dataset owned and managed by WPP Data Catalogue **What:** Mindshare's Chart of the Week - Data exploring if the boundaries of relationships are becoming more open. With half of all marriages ending in divorce, we are seeing more couples deciding to live together before they tie the knot. Is this as a dry run for marriage or to ensure they have truly found the one? Additionally, almost 2 in 5 of adults with young families globally (those who are living with their partner and children under the age of 7) are using an online dating service monthly, according to Mindreader. In India where the divorce rate is less than 1%, more than half of the online population in a young family are using online dating sites. In fact, the percentage of females (55%) is higher than their male counterparts (50%). Does this mean the boundaries of relationships are becoming more open? **When:** 18 November 2019 **Auto-Sync:** NA **Cite:** Chart of the Week, Mindshare, WPP Data Catalogue

name: Mindshare - Chart of the Week - Social Media
description: Mindshare's Chart of the Week explores "Is social media dominated by the silent majority?"
summary: --- {"editor":"simple"} --- **Data Origin:** Mindshare **Who:** Dataset owned and managed by WPP Data Catalogue **What:** Mindshare's Chart of the Week - Data exploring whether social media is dominated by the silent majority. More and more we are looking to social media to understand our consumers, but are we hearing from everyone? Globally, almost 60% of daily uploads (photos and streaming) to social networking sites are made by online people 18-34, but the majority (54%) of daily social networking users are over 35. This disparity suggests that over 35’s are more likely to regularly view social content than create. Is this true of all markets? Check out our Chart of the Week to compare each country’s social networking landscape. **When:** 7 October 2019 **Auto-Sync:** NA **Cite:** Chart of the Week, Mindshare, WPP Data Catalogue

name: Mindshare - Chart of the Week - Stereotypes
description: Mindshare's Chart of the Week: Do stereotypes still exist?
summary: --- {"editor":"simple"} --- **Data Origin:** Mindshare **Who:** Dataset owned and managed by WPP Data Catalogue **What:** Mindshare's Chart of the Week - Data supporting the question: Do stereotypes still exist? Interests explored include alcohol consumption, motor vehicles / cars, fashion / beauty, childcare / babies, sports, and more. Morally we all know that prejudices exist, but fortunately for us all they don´t last for ever. In many cases, they no longer reflect the reality. Mindreader data reveals which interests are more popular among males and females. We will find some stereotypes still linger but many have become old fashioned, from both male and female perspectives. **When:** Uploaded January 2020 **Auto-Sync:** NA **Cite:** Chart of the Week, Mindshare, WPP Data Catalogue ​

name: Mindshare - Chart of the Week - Tech Trendsetters
description: Mindshare's Chart of the Week explores "Who are today's technology trendsetters?"
summary: --- {"editor":"simple"} --- **Data Origin:** Mindshare **Who:** Dataset owned and managed by WPP Data Catalogue **What:** Mindshare's Chart of the Week - Data exploring who today's tech trendsetters are. Technology has become integral to our daily lives. However, tech trendsetters are the ones to push the boundaries of the mainstream, for the masses to follow. When we think about early adopters of technology, the stereotype of young males living in Silicon Valley comes to mind. Yet, globally, according to Mindreader, people with high income (‘Upmarket Adults’) are the most likely to be the first ones in their group of friends to have the latest technology, followed by ‘Young Men (18-34)’. Check out our Chart of the Week to know who the tech early adopters are in the different countries. **When:** 28 October 2019 **Auto-Sync:** NA **Cite:** Chart of the Week, Mindshare, WPP Data Catalogue

name: Mindshare - Chart of the Week - Travel Democratization
description: Mindshare's chart of the week data on the democratization of travel.
summary: --- {"editor":"simple"} --- **Data Origin:** Mindshare **Who:** Dataset owned and managed by WPP Data Catalogue **What:** Mindshare's Chart of the Week - Data exploring the democratization of travel. Explores travel purpose - business vs. leisure of the world's online population. Air travel, especially abroad, was a luxury only accessible for a small portion of the population until the 90s. Airline’s low-cost operations, deregulation of the market, and the commercialization of the internet were the 3 combined factors that democratised air travelling and changed the hospitality industry. Globally, 71% of the online population travelled abroad last year (70% for pleasure and 35% for work). **When:** Uploaded January 2020 **Auto-Sync:** NA **Cite:** Chart of the Week, Mindshare, WPP Data Catalogue

name: Mindshare - Chart of the Week - Websites/Apps by Life Stage
description: Mindshare's Chart of the Week explores "Does our selection of websites / apps change depending on our life stage?"
summary: --- {"editor":"simple"} --- **Data Origin:** Mindshare **Who:** Dataset owned and managed by WPP Data Catalogue **What:** Mindshare's Chart of the Week - Data exploring whether our selection of websites/apps change depending on our life stage. It is a universal truth that as we go through the different milestones in life the proportion of our time spent online changes – families with teens are 7% more likely to be online daily than seniors. Does, however, our life stage also have an impact on which websites/apps we choose to use when we are online? Our Mindreader study shows that globally platforms like Google or Facebook are popular across all lifestages. However, that is not the case for all websites/apps. Young singles are 14% more likely to be on YouTube than families with children, while young couples are 15% more likely to be on Instagram than families with children. **When:** 9 December 2019 **Auto-Sync:** NA **Cite:** Chart of the Week, Mindshare, WPP Data Catalogue

name: Mindshare - Chart of the Week - Women in Sports
description: Mindshare's Chart of the Week explores the topic "Women in Sports"
summary: --- {"editor":"simple"} --- **Data Origin:** Mindshare **Who:** Dataset owned and managed by WPP Data Catalogue **What:** Mindshare's Chart of the Week - Data exploring: Women in Sports; Contains data around women in sports and women's behaviour towards sports and athletics Is women’s behaviour towards sport changing as they become the media’s centre of attention? There has been an increase of media attention around women in sports, emphasising gender parity and surfacing problems, such as equal pay, their performance pre and post the birth of children and juggling motherhood as elite athletes. Their behaviour on the field, the coverage of female events by media/brands sponsorship has also been scrutinised. Recent front page coverage of these issues, has pushed FIFA to double the prize money of Women's World Cup in 2023, which still remains miles behind the men’s prize at $400 million. Even though Serena Williams lost this weekend, the current number one tennis player in the world, amongst men and women, is usually at the centre of media controversy: in the Australian Open 2017, media focused on her eight week pregnancy when she won her title and again in 2018 she berated umpire Carlos Ramos during the US Open final and was judged for it. Are we still a conservative society? Will this change come from media, brands, organisations, female players or the audience? Mindreader can prove that females are interested more in sports today compared to previous years. **When:** Uploaded January 2020 **Auto-Sync:** NA **Cite:** Chart of the Week, Mindshare, WPP Data Catalogue

For example “a dog is a kind of animal” or “captain can have the same meaning as master.” They were then asked if the sentence could be true and ranked it on a 1-5 scale. summary: --- {"editor":"simple"} --- **Data Origin:** Figure Eight **Source Description:** Open Images is a dataset of 9 million images that have been annotated with image-level labels and bounding boxes spanning thousands of classes. Version 4 of Open Images focuses on object detection, with bounding boxes annotated across 1.9 million images. The annotations cover 600 classes of objects, grouped hierarchically. We collaborated with Computer Vision scientists from Google to host this dataset, and it is the feature set for the [Open Images Challenge 2019](https://storage.googleapis.com/openimages/web/challenge2019.html), the detection and segmentation challenge at the [International Conference on Computer Vision 2019 (ICCV 2019)](http://iccv2019.thecvf.com/). For more on the Open Images Dataset, [you can head here.](https://storage.googleapis.com/openimages/web/index.html) Download Options are available on Figure Eight [here](https://www.figure-eight.com/dataset/open-images-annotated-with-bounding-boxes/). **When:** 2020 **Cite:** Open Images Dataset v5 (Bounding Boxes), Figure Eight **Licensing:** Licensed under a [Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License](http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/). name: Primary Commodity Prices
description: Indices, market prices, and average weekly prices for petroleum and non-fuel commodities.
summary: --- {"editor":"simple"} --- **Data Origin:** Open data linked via [@imf](https://data.world/imf) **Who:** Dataset owned and managed by International Monetary Fund **What:** * **Geographic Coverage: B**enchmark prices which are representative of the global market. They are determined by the largest exporter of a given commodity. * **Methodology:** Prices are period averages in nominal U.S. dollars. The current and the previous weights are provided in the comparison table on the website. The weights are calculated about every 5 years. The weights in the commodity basket reflect the structure of trade in 2002-2004 (previously it was 1995-1997). The choice of years reflects the desire of getting the most updated weights possible but still having sufficient data to improve accuracy. As part of the update, a thorough research into the basket of commodities was conducted to see whether the items included earlier are still representative in global commodities trade. The rule of thumb is that their share in total commodities trade has to be 3 percent or more of total commodities trade, in value terms. From this process, coconut oil was taken out and rapeseed oil was included in the new index. In recent years, the amount of coconut oil traded has decreased, while the trade of rapeseed has increased due to its use for canola oil and bio-diesel production. Also, commodity descriptions, sources and weights are available as part of the dataset. Price indices are based in 2005 (average of 2005 = 100). First individual commodity price indices are calculate in U.S. dollar and SDR terms, basing the price series in those currencies in 2005. Group indices are weighted averages of individual commodity price indices, with respective commodity weights derived from their relative trade values compared to the total world trade as reported in the UN Comtrade database. **When:** The data are annual, quarterly and monthly and go back to 1980. **Type:** Time Series **Updated:** Annually **Source Description:** "Indices in terms of dollars or sdrs, indices of market prices for non-fuel commodities and petroleum, actual market prices for non-fuel commodities and petroleum, and average weekly prices for non-fuel commodities and petroleum." **Cite:** Primary Commodity Prices, International Monetary Fund The Data is provided to Users “as is” and without warranty of any kind, either express or implied, including, without limitation, warranties of merchantability, fitness for a particular purpose and noninfringement. The IMF Data is available free of charge from the IMF. Users are prohibited from infringing upon the integrity of the IMF data and in particular shall refrain from any act of alteration of the IMF data that intentionally affects its nature or accuracy. If the IMF data is materially transformed by the user, this must be stated explicitly along with the required source citation. All other terms set forth in the IMF's general terms and conditions ([http://www.imf.org/external/terms.htm](http://www.imf.org/external/terms.htm)) shall continue to apply to use of IMF Data. **_Source:_** [http://data.imf.org/?sk=388DFA60-1D26-4ADE-B505-A05A558D9A42&sId=1479329132344](http://data.imf.org/?sk=388DFA60-1D26-4ADE-B505-A05A558D9A42&sId=1479329132344)

name: National Public Health Profiles - Public Health England
description: CCG-level data on risk factors for conditions with high impact on death rate (Fingertips).
summary: --- {"editor":"simple"} --- **Data Origin:** Public Health England **Description:** **We (WPP) have linked 3 National Public Health Profiles (Overview tables only) sourced from Public Health England (Cancer, Cardiovascular Disease, and Diabetes). For additional data, please review the below documentation and visit the source website.** **Case Study:** This data has been used by Wavemaker (WPP) alongside the [Report of the WHO-China Joint Mission on Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19)](https://www.who.int/docs/default-source/coronaviruse/who-china-joint-mission-on-covid-19-final-report.pdf) to develop a model for predicting the seriousness levels of the virus if it were to hit certain areas of England. After composite risk scores were assigned to every local area, the team built mapping tools to support thier planning teams and clients to understand which areas have the highest risk of excess mortality per case of coronavirus. As of 23 March 2020, 58 critical locations containing 31% of England's population have been identified that over-index heavily on those at risk. This tool is currently being used by Wavemaker to re-weight media plans to ensure high coverage and frequency of key public health messages in areas where people are high-risk. ![https://media.data.world/kmCroM1qSjq64f0JE8s2\_image.png](https://media.data.world/kmCroM1qSjq64f0JE8s2_image.png) ![https://media.data.world/vnVRhjiISnmMlw3XhzXA\_image.png](https://media.data.world/vnVRhjiISnmMlw3XhzXA_image.png) ![https://media.data.world/3pKBO3SWS7mwLnSsnKdu\_image.png](https://media.data.world/3pKBO3SWS7mwLnSsnKdu_image.png) **About the profiles** These profiles are a rich source of indicators across a range of health and wellbeing themes that has been designed to support JSNA and commissioning to improve health and wellbeing, and reduce inequalities. With these profiles you can: * Browse indicators at different geographical levels * Benchmark against the regional or England average * Export data to use locally These profiles have been developed by Public Health England. See [New features](https://fingertips.phe.org.uk/profile/guidance/supporting-information/new-features) for information about new functionality. **Get the data with R** The [fingertipsR](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/fingertipsR/index.html) package allows you to download public health data using R **Get the data with Python** The [fingertips\_py](https://fingertips-py.readthedocs.io/en/latest) package allows you to download public health data using Python **Public Health Data API** The [Fingertips API](https://fingertips.phe.org.uk/api) (Chrome or Firefox only) allows public health data to be retrieved in either JSON or CSV formats **Data sharing and reuse** You may re-use this information (excluding logos) free of charge in any format or medium, under the terms of the Open Government Licence v.3.0 To view this licence, visit OGL. Where we have identified any third party copyright information you will need to obtain permission from the copyright holders concerned. **Please cite any use of this website as follows specifying the date of access:** 'Public Health England. Public Health Profiles. [Date accessed] [https://fingertips.phe.org.uk](https://fingertips.phe.org.uk/) © Crown copyright [Year]' **When:** March 2020

name: San Francisco Parking Sign Detection
description: Parking sign detection and parsing from images of Francisco streets.
summary: --- {"editor":"simple"} --- **Data Origin:** Figure Eight **Source Description:** This dataset contains images of parking signs in different shapes, colors, orientations and sizes collected from different neighborhoods in San Francisco and annotated using Figure Eight platform, enabling model training for detecting parking signs in the city. These annotated parking signs can help train OCR models to understand relevant signage for parking and self-driving cars, teaching models to ignore store signage, billboards, and other potentially confusing outdoor text. Parking sign detection combines computer vision, natural language processing, and spatial reasoning and is currently an ongoing project at Figure Eight. Our goal is to further the study using deep learning methods to build more accurate models and extend the parking sign detections to other cities and in particular dense areas where parking signs could be confused with man-made objects. [To learn more about this project, please read this paper](https://ascelibrary.org/doi/abs/10.1061/9780784480823.037). **When:** 2020 **Auto-Sync:** Weekly **Cite:** San Francisco Parking Sign Detection, Figure Eight **Licensing:** Licensed under a [Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License](http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/). By taking the action of downloading any data set(s), you hereby agree to the associated license terms. Each data set is provided “as is” and any expressed or implied warranties, including, but not limited to, the implied warranties of merchantability and fitness for a particular purpose are disclaimed.

name: Semantic relationships between two concepts
description: An interesting language data set about the relationship of broad concepts.
summary: --- {"editor":"simple"} --- **Data Origin:** Figure Eight **Who:** Dataset owned and managed by WPP Data Catalogue **What:** An interesting language data set about the relationship of broad concepts. All questions were phrased in the following way: “All [x] are [y].” For example, a contributor would see something like “All **Toyotas** are **vehicles**” and were then asked to say whether this claim was true or false. Contributors were also provided images, in case they were unclear as to what either concept is. This data set includes links to both images provided, the names given for [x] and [y], and whether the statement that “All [x] are [y]” was true or false. **When:** 2014 **Auto-Sync:** Weekly **Cite:** Semantic Relationships Between Two Concepts, Figure Eight
